STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 1, 2022
Amy Bailey
Pathways of Arbor Circle
412 Century Lane
Holland, MI 49423
RE: License #: CB700201042
Pathways of Arbor Circle
412 Century Lane
Holland, MI 49423
Dear Ms. Bailey:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
5/23-27/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MSA
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

Licensee Name: Arbor Circle Corporation
Licensee Address: 1115 Ball NE
Grand Rapids, MI 49505

Name of Facility: Pathways of Arbor Circle

Holland, MI 49423

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient number of
competent staff to carry out the provisions covered by these
rules. The workload for each staff member shall not be more
than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker for the
purpose of providing direct services in foster care, independent
living, adoption, or post adoption services or a combination
thereof.
1 of 13 caseload carrying staff is currently outside of caseload compliance
requirements. This worker is an adoption worker who currently has 16 youth on her
caseload.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
1 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed contained documentation that the initial
dental exam was not completed within the required timeframe.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child's date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of
the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
4

child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency medical care.
1 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed are not in compliance with subsections a,
b, c, d, e, f, g, h, and i as evidenced by documentation that the information required
to be provided to the new caregiver prior to or at replacement of a youth was not
provided timely.
2 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed are not in compliance with subsection j as
evidenced by documentation that the required medical authorization card was
completed and provided outside of the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED subsection j previously cited as FOM 801
Renewal Inspection report 6/9/2020, CAP Approved 7/14/2020
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
1 of 9 open case files reviewed (8 foster care, 1 IL) contained one service plan
completed one day late.
R 400.12511 Independent living contract.
(1) When an agency terminates its independent living services
for a youth, the agency shall document all of the following
information in the case record within 30 calendar days of
termination of its services:
(a) The reason for the termination.
(b) The youth's new location.
(c) A summary of the services provided during care and the
needs that remain to be met.
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
2 of 2 closed IL files did not contain documentation of all of the requirements of
subsection a, b, c, or d of this rule.
R 400.12511 Independent living contract.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each youth who
ends independent living is provided with all of the following:
(a) Basic information about health, housing, counseling/mental
health services, and emergency resources.
(b) A birth certificate.
(c) A social security card.
5

(d) The youth's funds and personal property.
1 of 2 closed IL files reviewed did not contain documentation that all information
required by subsections a, b, c, and d was provided to the youth at closure.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing
an adoption application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.
2 of 3 Adoptive Family Assessments reviewed were not completed within the
required timeframe.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-07F PERMANENCY PLANNING - PPFWR AND APPLA
The DHS-643, Permanency Goal Review, is the change form for
all changes and reviews of permanency goals. For PPFWR and
APPLA, within 30 calendar days of a change in the relative
placement or the supportive adult, and within 30 calendar days
of the annual review date, the DHS-643, Permanency Goal
Review, must be completed and submitted to the permanency
resource monitor for review. Note: Additional permanency plan
approval packet documentation may be required depending on
the reason for review. Annual Review Date The annual review
date is calculated from permanency goal established date; see
Changing the Permanency Goal in this item.
1 of 1 open IL files reviewed did not contain an annual permanency goal review form
(DHS-643).
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
6

 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed
apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check yes
or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
treatment plan, the caseworker must identify and document
actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the
treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
3 of 9 open case files reviewed (8FC, 1 IL) did not contain signatures obtained within
the required timeframe on all PATPs.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as FOM 722-08C
Interim Inspection Report 6/14/2021, CAP Approved 6/30/2021
Renewal Inspection report 6/9/2020, CAP Approved 7/14/2020
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
7

Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
3 of 15 total case files reviewed (9 open, 6 closed) did not contain all required action
summaries completed completely and within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as FOM 722-09C
Interim Inspection Report 6/14/2021, CAP Approved 6/30/2021
Renewal Inspection report 6/9/2020, CAP Approved 7/14/2020
FOM 722-16 YOUNG ADULT VOLUNTARY FOSTER CARE
Ongoing verification of eligibility is required, at minimum,
quarterly, to coincide with the case service plan due date. The
supervisor must review and verify the youth’s eligibility prior to
approving the case service plan. If the youth does not meet
eligibility requirements, see Reporting Eligibility Changes in this
item. The caseworker must provide the youth with the
appropriate eligibility verification form at least 45 calendar days
prior to the case service plan due date. The caseworker must
discuss a youth's eligibility at each monthly face-to-face contact.
The youth's failure to notify the caseworker of eligibility changes
in a timely manner will not delay the beginning of a grace period
or case closure. For example, a caseworker can request to see
paystubs or work schedule each month to make sure the youth
is meeting requirements. Exception: The DHS-54A, Medical
Needs form, may be submitted on an annual basis if the youth’s
condition is expected to persist for more than one year, and
there is a pending application for SSI.
1 of 1 open IL files reviewed did not contain quarterly verification of eligibility
documentation.
ADM 980 ADOPTION CLOSING SUMMARY (DHS-222)
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14 calendar
days of the adoption finalization date to the foster care worker
8

and the Department of Health and Services (DHHS) adoption
monitor for purchase of service cases for inclusion in the child’s
permanent record. The DHS-222, Adoption Closing Summary
must be used for this purpose.
1 of 2 closed adoption files reviewed contained an adoption finalization report which
was not completed within the required timeframe.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Medical Passport documents must be saved in the correct hyperlink.
 When completing closing action summaries, all required areas must be
completed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
No consultation was required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
This corrective action plan was in response to the licensing interim inspection report
dated 6/14/2021 and was approved on 6/30/2020. The agency staff have achieved
and sustained compliance in all areas of that corrective action plan except for policy
requirements FOM 722-08D and FOM 722-08E. These repeat violations are
regarding obtaining Parent Agency Treatment Plan signatures and completion of
Action Summaries. Compliance in the area of obtaining required signatures has
declined slightly as the 2021 inspection cited 1 of 6 files and the current citation is for
3 of 9 files. Compliance in the area of completing action summaries has also
declined slightly as the 2021 inspection cited 1 of 10 files in violation and the current
inspection cites 3 of 15 files. Regardless of these declines, the agency shows overall
compliance improvement as evidenced by the minimum number of repeat violations.
Chief Administrator Assessment – The chief administrator assessment
documented a thorough and accurate review and assessment of the program. The
chief administrator identified areas of non-compliance which accurately reflected the
citations found in this licensing review.
9

Staff Interviews – All of the staff interviewed reported feeling supported by peers and
superiors. They all identified a work environment in which help is available whenever
needed and regular and effective communication occurs at all levels of staff.
VII. DCWL ANALYST CONCERNS
No safety concerns were identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
May 31, 2021
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 1, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
10
